standard_metadata.standard_description: Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context.

question.content: The following data points represent the number of quesadillas each person at Toby's Tacos ate.  *Answer $2$ questions about the data set.*  1. **Sort the data from least to greatest.**    2. **Find the interquartile range (IQR) of the data set.**   quesadillas

hints.content: The **interquartile range** is the amount of spread in the middle $50\%$ of the data set.  It is the positive difference between the third quartile and the first quartile.  $\text{IQR} = Q_3-Q_1$  Make sure to sort the numbers before finding the median, $Q_1$, and $Q_3$!

To find the quartiles, let's first find the median by sorting the data points from least to greatest.    $\underbrace{0\text{, }0\text{, }\dfrac{1}{4}\text{, }\dfrac{1}{2}\text{, }\dfrac{1}{2}}_\text{lower half}\text{, }  \purpleD{1}\text{, }\underbrace{1\text{, }1\text{, }\dfrac{5}{4}\text{, }2\text{, }2}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points. So the median is the middle number.  The median is $\purpleD{1}$.  We *do not* include the median when we calculate the quartiles.

The **first quartile** is the median of the data points  to the *left* of the median.  $\underbrace{0\text{, }0\text{, }\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}\text{, }\dfrac{1}{2}\text{, }\dfrac{1}{2}}_\text{lower half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points in the lower half. So the first quartile is the middle number.  $Q_{1} = \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$

The **third quartile** is the median of the data points to the *right* of the median.  $\underbrace{1\text{, }1\text{, }\tealE{\dfrac{5}{4}}\text{, }2\text{, }2}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points in the upper half. So the third quartile is the middle number.  $Q_{3} = \tealE{\dfrac54}$
$\begin{align} \text{IQR} &= Q_3-Q_1  \\\\ &=  \tealE{\dfrac{5}{4}} - \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}} \\\\ &= \dfrac{4}{4} \\\\ &= 1 \end{align}$

The data from least to greatest is:  $0$, $0$, $\dfrac14$, $\dfrac12$, $\dfrac12$, $1$, $1$, $1$, $\dfrac54$, $2$, $2$  *Did you remember to sort the numbers?*  The interquartile range is $1$ quesadilla.

question.content: The following data points represent the number of animal crackers in each kid's lunch box.  *Answer $2$ questions about the data set.*  1. **Sort the data from least to greatest.**    2. **Find the interquartile range (IQR) of the data set.**   animal crackers

hints.content: The **interquartile range** is the amount of spread in the middle $50\%$ of the data set.  It is the positive difference between the third quartile and the first quartile.  $\text{IQR} = Q_3-Q_1$  Make sure to sort the numbers before finding the median, $Q_1$, and $Q_3$!

To find the quartiles, let's first find the median by sorting the data points from least to greatest.    $\underbrace{4\text{, }4\text{, }6\text{, }7}_\text{lower half}\text{, }\purpleD{10}\text{, }\underbrace{11\text{, }12\text{, }14\text{, }15}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points. So the median is the middle number.  The median is $\purpleD{10}$.  We *do not* include the median when we calculate the quartiles.

The **first quartile** is the median of the data points  to the *left* of the median.  $\underbrace{4\text{, }\blueE{4}\text{, }\blueE{6}\text{, }7}_\text{lower half}$  There was an *even* number of data points in the lower half. So the first quartile is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $Q_{1} = \dfrac{\blueE{4} + \blueE{6}}{2} = \dfrac{10}{2}= \maroonD{5}$

The **third quartile** is the median of the data points to the *right* of the median.  $\underbrace{11\text{, }\goldE{12}\text{, }\goldE{14}\text{, }15}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *even* number of data points in the upper half. So the third quartile is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $Q_{3} = \dfrac{\goldE{12} + \goldE{14}}{2} = \dfrac{26}{2}= \tealE{13}$
$\begin{align} \text{IQR} &= Q_3-Q_1  \\\\ &=  \tealE{13} - \maroonD{5} \\\\ &= 8 \end{align}$
The data from least to greatest is:  $4$, $4$, $6$, $7$, $10$, $11$, $12$, $14$, $15$  *Did you remember to sort the numbers?*  The interquartile range is $8$ animal crackers.

question.content: A family of bears is going to a movie. The following data points represent the ticket and candy price (in dollars) for each bear.  *Answer $2$ questions about the data set.*  1. **Sort the data from least to greatest.**    2. **Find the interquartile range (IQR) of the data set.**     dollars

hints.content: The **interquartile range** is the amount of spread in the middle $50\%$ of the data set.  It is the positive difference between the third quartile and the first quartile.  $\text{IQR} = Q_3-Q_1$  Make sure to sort the numbers before finding the median, $Q_1$, and $Q_3$!

To find the quartiles, let's first find the median by sorting the data points from least to greatest.    $\underbrace{0\text{, }1\dfrac12\text{, }2\dfrac12\text{, }3}_\text{lower half}\text{, }\purpleD{4}\text{, }\underbrace{4\text{, }4\text{, }7\text{, }7\dfrac12}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points. So the median is the middle number.  The median is $\purpleD{4}$.  We *do not* include the median when we calculate the quartiles.

The **first quartile** is the median of the data points  to the *left* of the median.  $\underbrace{0\text{, }\blueE{1\dfrac12}\text{, }\blueE{2\dfrac12}\text{, }3}_\text{lower half}$  There was an *even* number of data points in the lower half. So the first quartile is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $Q_{1} = \dfrac{\blueE{1 \dfrac12} + \blueE{2 \dfrac12}}{2} = \dfrac{4}{2}= \maroonD{2}$

The **third quartile** is the median of the data points to the *right* of the median.  $\underbrace{4\text{, }\goldE{4}\text{, }\goldE{7}\text{, }7\dfrac12}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *even* number of data points in the upper half. So the third quartile is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $Q_{3} = \dfrac{\goldE{4} + \goldE{7}}{2} = \dfrac{11}{2}= \tealE{5.5}$
$\begin{align} \text{IQR} &= Q_3-Q_1  \\\\ &=  \tealE{5.5} - \maroonD{2} \\\\ &= 3.5 \end{align}$
The data from least to greatest is:  $0$, $1 \dfrac12$, $2 \dfrac12$, $3$, $4$, $4$, $4$, $7$, $7 \dfrac12$  *Did you remember to sort the numbers?*  The interquartile range is $3.5$ dollars.

question.content: The following data points represent the number of remote controllers each student in Tria's video game club owns.  *Answer $2$ questions about the data set.*  1. **Sort the data from least to greatest.**    2. **Find the interquartile range (IQR) of the data set.**   remote controllers

hints.content: The **interquartile range** is the amount of spread in the middle $50\%$ of the data set.  It is the positive difference between the third quartile and the first quartile.  $\text{IQR} = Q_3-Q_1$  Make sure to sort the numbers before finding the median, $Q_1$, and $Q_3$!

To find the quartiles, let's first find the median by sorting the data points from least to greatest.    $\underbrace{0\text{, }0\text{, }0\text{, }1\text{, }2}_\text{lower half}\text{, }\purpleD{2}\text{, }\underbrace{4\text{, }5\text{, }7\text{, }8\text{, }10}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points. So the median is the middle number.  The median is $\purpleD{2}$.  We *do not* include the median when we calculate the quartiles.

The **first quartile** is the median of the data points  to the *left* of the median.  $\underbrace{0\text{, }0\text{, }\maroonD{0}\text{, }1\text{, }2}_\text{lower half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points in the lower half. So the first quartile is the middle number.  $Q_{1} = \maroonD{0}$

The **third quartile** is the median of the data points to the *right* of the median.  $\underbrace{4\text{, }5\text{, }\tealE{7}\text{, }8\text{, }10}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points in the upper half. So the third quartile is the middle number.  $Q_{3} = \tealE{7}$
$\begin{align} \text{IQR} &= Q_3-Q_1  \\\\ &=  \tealE{7} - \maroonD{0} \\\\ &= 7 \end{align}$
The data from least to greatest is:  $0$, $0$, $0$, $1$, $2$, $2$, $4$, $5$, $7$, $8$, $10$  *Did you remember to sort the numbers?*  The interquartile range is $7$ remote controllers.

question.content: The following data points represent the number of classes that each teacher at Broxin High School teaches.  *Answer $2$ questions about the data set.*  1. **Sort the data from least to greatest.**    2. **Find the interquartile range (IQR) of the data set.**   classes

hints.content: The **interquartile range** is the amount of spread in the middle $50\%$ of the data set.  It is the positive difference between the third quartile and the first quartile.  $\text{IQR} = Q_3-Q_1$  Make sure to sort the numbers before finding the median, $Q_1$, and $Q_3$!

To find the quartiles, let's first find the median by sorting the data points from least to greatest.    $\underbrace{1\text{, }1\text{, }3\text{, }4\text{, }4}_\text{lower half}\text{, }\purpleD{5}\text{, }\underbrace{5\text{, }5\text{, }6\text{, }7\text{, }9}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points. So the median is the middle number.  The median is $\purpleD{5}$.  We *do not* include the median when we calculate the quartiles.

The **first quartile** is the median of the data points  to the *left* of the median.  $\underbrace{1\text{, }1\text{, }\maroonD{3}\text{, }4\text{, }4}_\text{lower half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points in the lower half. So the first quartile is the middle number.  $Q_{1} = \maroonD{3}$

The **third quartile** is the median of the data points to the *right* of the median.  $\underbrace{5\text{, }5\text{, }\tealE{6}\text{, }7\text{, }9}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points in the upper half. So the third quartile is the middle number.  $Q_{3} = \tealE{6}$
$\begin{align} \text{IQR} &= Q_3-Q_1  \\\\ &=  \tealE{6} - \maroonD{3} \\\\ &= 3 \end{align}$
The data from least to greatest is:  $1$, $1$, $3$, $4$, $4$, $5$, $5$, $5$, $6$, $7$, $9$  *Did you remember to sort the numbers?*  The interquartile range is $3$ classes.

question.content: The following data points represent the number of points scored by each player on the Wildcats basketball team last game.  *Answer $2$ questions about the data set.*  1. **Sort the data from least to greatest.**    2. **Find the interquartile range (IQR) of the data set.**   points

hints.content: The **interquartile range** is the amount of spread in the middle $50\%$ of the data set.  It is the positive difference between the third quartile and the first quartile.  $\text{IQR} = Q_3-Q_1$  Make sure to sort the numbers before finding the median, $Q_1$, and $Q_3$!

To find the quartiles, let's first find the median by sorting the data points from least to greatest.    $\underbrace{4\text{, }5\text{, }6\text{, }\redE{8}}_\text{lower half} \text{, } \underbrace{\redE{9}\text{, }10\text{, }11\text{, }13}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *even* number of data points. So the median is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $\dfrac{\redE{8} + \redE{9}}{2} = \purpleD{8.5}$ points  We *do not* include the median when we calculate the quartiles, but we *do* include the numbers we averaged to get it.

The **first quartile** is the median of the data points  to the *left* of the median.  $\underbrace{4\text{, }\blueE{5}\text{, }\blueE{6}\text{, }{8}}_\text{lower half}$  There was an *even* number of data points in the lower half. So the first quartile is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $Q_{1} = \dfrac{\blueE{5} + \blueE{6}}{2} = \dfrac{11}{2}= \maroonD{5.5}$

The **third quartile** is the median of the data points to the *right* of the median.  $\underbrace{{9}\text{, }\goldE{10}\text{, }\goldE{11}\text{, }13}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *even* number of data points in the upper half. So the third quartile is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $Q_{3} = \dfrac{\goldE{10} + \goldE{11}}{2} = \dfrac{21}{2}= \tealE{10.5}$
$\begin{align} \text{IQR} &= Q_3-Q_1  \\\\ &=  \tealE{10.5} - \maroonD{5.5} \\\\ &= 5 \end{align}$
The data from least to greatest is:  $4$, $5$, $6$, $8$, $9$, $10$, $11$, $13$  *Did you remember to sort the numbers?*  The interquartile range is $5$ points.

question.content: The following data points represent the number of attendees at each of the dance events hosted by Cloy Events.  *Answer $2$ questions about the data set.*  1. **Sort the data from least to greatest.**    2. **Find the interquartile range (IQR) of the data set.**   attendees

hints.content: The **interquartile range** is the amount of spread in the middle $50\%$ of the data set.  It is the positive difference between the third quartile and the first quartile.  $\text{IQR} = Q_3-Q_1$  Make sure to sort the numbers before finding the median, $Q_1$, and $Q_3$!

To find the quartiles, let's first find the median by sorting the data points from least to greatest.    $\underbrace{32\text{, }34\text{, }35\text{, }\redE{35}}_\text{lower half}\text{, }\underbrace{\redE{39}\text{, }40\text{, }44\text{, }47}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *even* number of data points. So the median is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $\dfrac{\redE{35} + \redE{39}}{2} = \dfrac{74}{2}= \purpleD{37} $ attendees  We *do not* include the median when we calculate the quartiles, but we *do* include the numbers we averaged to get it.

The **first quartile** is the median of the data points  to the *left* of the median.  $\underbrace{32\text{, }\blueE{34}\text{, }\blueE{35}\text{, }{35}}_\text{lower half}$  There was an *even* number of data points in the lower half. So the first quartile is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $Q_{1} = \dfrac{\blueE{34} + \blueE{35}}{2} = \dfrac{69}{2}= \maroonD{34.5}$

The **third quartile** is the median of the data points to the *right* of the median.  $\underbrace{{39}\text{, }\goldE{40}\text{, }\goldE{44}\text{, }47}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *even* number of data points in the upper half. So the third quartile is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $Q_{3} = \dfrac{\goldE{40} + \goldE{44}}{2} = \dfrac{84}{2}= \tealE{42}$
$\begin{align} \text{IQR} &= Q_3-Q_1  \\\\ &=  \tealE{42} - \maroonD{34.5} \\\\ &= 7.5 \end{align}$
The data from least to greatest is:  $32$, $34$, $35$, $35$, $39$, $40$, $44$, $47$  *Did you remember to sort the numbers?*  The interquartile range is $7.5$ attendees.

question.content: The following data points represent the volume of gas in each race car driver's tank (in liters).  *Answer $2$ questions about the data set.*  1. **Sort the data from least to greatest.**    2. **Find the interquartile range (IQR) of the data set.**   $\text{L}$

hints.content: The **interquartile range** is the amount of spread in the middle $50\%$ of the data set.  It is the positive difference between the third quartile and the first quartile.  $\text{IQR} = Q_3-Q_1$  Make sure to sort the numbers before finding the median, $Q_1$, and $Q_3$!

To find the quartiles, let's first find the median by sorting the data points from least to greatest.    $\underbrace{2.8\text{, }4\text{, }4.3\text{, }6\text{, }\redE{7.5}}_\text{lower half}$, $\underbrace{\redE{8.5}\text{, }9\text{, }11.6\text{, }12\text{, }12.1}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *even* number of data points. So the median is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $\dfrac{\redE{7.5} + \redE{8.5}}{2} =\dfrac{16}{2}= \purpleD{8}$  We *do not* include the median when we calculate the quartiles, but we *do* include the numbers we averaged to get it.

The **first quartile** is the median of the data points  to the *left* of the median.  $\underbrace{2.8\text{, }4\text{, }\maroonD{4.3}\text{, }6\text{, }{7.5}}_\text{lower half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points in the lower half. So the first quartile is the middle number.  $Q_{1} = \maroonD{4.3}$

The **third quartile** is the median of the data points to the *right* of the median.  $\underbrace{{8.5}\text{, }9\text{, }\tealE{11.6}\text{, }12\text{, }12.1}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points in the upper half. So the third quartile is the middle number.  $Q_{3} = \tealE{11.6}$
$\begin{align} \text{IQR} &= Q_3-Q_1  \\\\ &=  \tealE{11.6} - \maroonD{4.3} \\\\ &= 7.3 \end{align}$
The data from least to greatest is:  $2.80$, $4$, $4.3$, $6$, $7.5$, $8.5$, $9$, $11.6$, $12$, $12.10$  *Did you remember to sort the numbers?*  The interquartile range is $7.3\,\text{L}$.

question.content: The following data points represent the number of hours each of the staff members at Daniel's Department Store slept Thanksgiving night.  *Answer $2$ questions about the data set.*  1. **Sort the data from least to greatest.**    2. **Find the interquartile range (IQR) of the data set.**   hours

hints.content: The **interquartile range** is the amount of spread in the middle $50\%$ of the data set.  It is the positive difference between the third quartile and the first quartile.  $\text{IQR} = Q_3-Q_1$  Make sure to sort the numbers before finding the median, $Q_1$, and $Q_3$!

To find the quartiles, let's first find the median by sorting the data points from least to greatest.    $\underbrace{2.6\text{, }3\text{, }4.9\text{, }5\text{, }\redE{5}}_\text{lower half}\text{, }\underbrace{\redE{6}\text{, }6\text{, }7.9\text{, }8\text{, }8.2}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *even* number of data points. So the median is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $\dfrac{\redE{5} + \redE{6}}{2} = \dfrac{11}{2}= \purpleD{5.5} $  We *do not* include the median when we calculate the quartiles, but we *do* include the numbers we averaged to get it.

The **first quartile** is the median of the data points  to the *left* of the median.  $\underbrace{2.6\text{, }3\text{, }\maroonD{4.9}\text{, }5\text{, }{5}}_\text{lower half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points in the lower half. So the first quartile is the middle number.  $Q_{1} = \maroonD{4.9}$

The **third quartile** is the median of the data points to the *right* of the median.  $\underbrace{{6}\text{, }6\text{, }\tealE{7.9}\text{, }8\text{, }8.2}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points in the upper half. So the third quartile is the middle number.  $Q_{3} = \tealE{7.9}$
$\begin{align} \text{IQR} &= Q_3-Q_1  \\\\ &=  \tealE{7.9} - \maroonD{4.9} \\\\ &= 3 \end{align}$
The data from least to greatest is:  $2.6$, $3$, $4.9$, $5$, $5$, $6$, $6$, $7.9$, $8$, $8.2$  *Did you remember to sort the numbers?*  The interquartile range is $3$ hours.

question.content: Each dot in the following dot plot represents the number of players at one table in Bev's bingo hall.    **Find the interquartile range (IQR)  of the data in the dot plot.**   players

images.alt: A dot plot has a horizontal axis labeled Number of players marked by 8 equidistant tick marks numbered from 0 to 7. Dots are plotted above the following: 0, 1; 1, 2; 3, 3; 4, 1; 5, 1; 7, 1.

hints.content: The **interquartile range** is the amount of spread in the middle $50\%$ of the data set.  It is the positive difference between the third quartile and the first quartile.  $\text{IQR} = Q_3-Q_1$

To find the quartiles, let's first find the median by listing the data points from least to greatest.    $\underbrace{0\text{, }1\text{, }1\text{, }3}_\text{lower half}\text{, }\purpleD{3}\text{, }\underbrace{3\text{, }4\text{, }5\text{, }7}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points. So the median is the middle number.  The median is $\purpleD{3}$.  We *do not* include the median when we calculate the quartiles.

The **first quartile** is the median of the data points  to the *left* of the median.  $\underbrace{0\text{, }\blueE{1}\text{, }\blueE{1}\text{, }3}_\text{lower half}$  There was an *even* number of data points in the lower half. So the first quartile is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $Q_{1} = \dfrac{\blueE{1} + \blueE{1}}{2} = \dfrac{2}{2}= \maroonD{1}$

The **third quartile** is the median of the data points to the *right* of the median.  $\underbrace{3\text{, }\goldE{4}\text{, }\goldE{5}\text{, }7}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *even* number of data points in the upper half. So the third quartile is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $Q_{3} = \dfrac{\goldE{4} + \goldE{5}}{2} = \dfrac{9}{2}= \tealE{4.5}$
$\begin{align} \text{IQR} &= Q_3-Q_1  \\\\ &=  \tealE{4.5} - \maroonD{1} \\\\ &= 3.5 \end{align}$
The interquartile range is $3.5$ players.

question.content: Each dot in the following dot plot represents the number of goals Luis scored in one lacrosse season.    **Find the interquartile range (IQR)  of the data in the dot plot.**    goals

images.alt: A dot plot has a horizontal axis labeled Number of goals numbered from 43 to 48. Dots are plotted above the following: 43, 1; 44, 3; 45, 1; 47, 1; 48, 2.

hints.content: The **interquartile range** is the amount of spread in the middle $50\%$ of the data set.  It is the positive difference between the third quartile and the first quartile.  $\text{IQR} = Q_3-Q_1$

To find the quartiles, let's first find the median by listing the data points from least to greatest.    $\underbrace{43\text{, }44\text{, }44\text{, }44}_\text{lower half}\text{, }\purpleD{{45}}\text{, }\underbrace{45\text{, }47\text{, }48\text{, }48}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points. So the median is the middle number.  The median is $\purpleD{45}$.  We *do not* include the median when we calculate the quartiles.

The **first quartile** is the median of the data points  to the *left* of the median.  $\underbrace{43\text{, }\blueE{44}\text{, }\blueE{44}\text{, }44}_\text{lower half}$  There was an *even* number of data points in the lower half. So the first quartile is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $Q_{1} = \dfrac{\blueE{44} + \blueE{44}}{2}= \dfrac{88}{2} = \maroonD{44}$

The **third quartile** is the median of the data points to the *right* of the median.  $\underbrace{45\text{, }\goldE{47}\text{, }\goldE{48}\text{, }48}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *even* number of data points in the upper half. So the third quartile is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $Q_{3} = \dfrac{\goldE{47} + \goldE{48}}{2} = \dfrac{95}{2}= \tealE{47.5}$
$\begin{align} \text{IQR} &= Q_3-Q_1  \\\\ &=  \tealE{47.5} - \maroonD{44} \\\\ &= 3.5 \end{align}$
The interquartile range is $3.5$ goals.

question.content: Each dot in the following dot plot represents the number of chocolate chips in one cookie in a package.    **Find the interquartile range (IQR)  of the data in the dot plot.**    chocolate chips

images.alt: A dot plot has a horizontal axis labeled Number of chocolate chips numbered from 0 to 10. Dots are plotted above the following: 2, 1; 3, 2; 4, 4; 5, 2; 6, 1; 7, 1.

hints.content: The **interquartile range** is the amount of spread in the middle $50\%$ of the data set.  It is the positive difference between the third quartile and the first quartile.  $\text{IQR} = Q_3-Q_1$

To find the quartiles, let's first find the median by listing the data points from least to greatest.    $\underbrace{2\text{, }3\text{, }3\text{, }4\text{, }4}_\text{lower half}\text{, }\purpleD{4}\text{, }\underbrace{4\text{, }5\text{, }5\text{, }6\text{, }7}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points. So the median is the middle number.  The median is $\purpleD{4}$.  We *do not* include the median when we calculate the quartiles.

The **first quartile** is the median of the data points  to the *left* of the median.  $\underbrace{2\text{, }3\text{, }\maroonD{3}\text{, }4\text{, }4}_\text{lower half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points in the lower half. So the first quartile is the middle number.  $Q_{1} = \maroonD{3}$

The **third quartile** is the median of the data points to the *right* of the median.  $\underbrace{4\text{, }5\text{, }\tealE{5}\text{, }6\text{, }7}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points in the upper half. So the third quartile is the middle number.  $Q_{3} = \tealE{5}$
$\begin{align} \text{IQR} &= Q_3-Q_1  \\\\ &=  \tealE{5} - \maroonD{3} \\\\ &= 2 \end{align}$
The interquartile range is $2$ chocolate chips.

question.content: Each dot in the following dot plot represents the number of jokers in one of Marcie's decks of cards.    **Find the interquartile range (IQR)  of the data in the dot plot.**   jokers

images.alt: A dot plot has a horizontal axis labeled Number of jokers numbered from 0 to 4. Dots are plotted above the following: 0, 3; 1, 1; 2, 5; 3, 1; 4, 1.

hints.content: The **interquartile range** is the amount of spread in the middle $50\%$ of the data set.  It is the positive difference between the third quartile and the first quartile.  $\text{IQR} = Q_3-Q_1$

To find the quartiles, let's first find the median by listing the data points from least to greatest.    $\underbrace{0\text{, }0\text{, }0\text{, }1\text{, }2}_\text{lower half}\text{, }\purpleD{2}\text{, }\underbrace{2\text{, }2\text{, }2\text{, }3\text{, }4}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points. So the median is the middle number.  The median is $\purpleD{2}$.  We *do not* include the median when we calculate the quartiles.

The **first quartile** is the median of the data points  to the *left* of the median.  $\underbrace{0\text{, }0\text{, }\maroonD{0}\text{, }1\text{, }2}_\text{lower half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points in the lower half. So the first quartile is the middle number.  $Q_{1} = \maroonD{0}$

The **third quartile** is the median of the data points to the *right* of the median.  $\underbrace{2\text{, }2\text{, }\tealE{2}\text{, }3\text{, }4}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points in the upper half. So the third quartile is the middle number.  $Q_{3} = \tealE{2}$
$\begin{align} \text{IQR} &= Q_3-Q_1  \\\\ &=  \tealE{2} - \maroonD{0} \\\\ &= 2 \end{align}$
The interquartile range is $2$ jokers.

question.content: Each dot in the following dot plot represents the height of one toddler at Mrs. Orlando's daycare.    **Find the interquartile range (IQR)  of the data in the dot plot.**   $\text{cm}$

images.alt:
"A dot plot.  The number line, labeled Height (centimeters), is numbered 80 to 86. 
The tick mark 81 has 1 dot.
The tick mark 82 has 1 dot.
The tick mark 83 has 2 dots. 
The tick mark 84 has 3 dots.
The tick mark 85 has 1 dot."

hints.content: The **interquartile range** is the amount of spread in the middle $50\%$ of the data set.  It is the positive difference between the third quartile and the first quartile.  $\text{IQR} = Q_3-Q_1$

To find the quartiles, let's first find the median by listing the data points from least to greatest.    $\underbrace{81\text{, }82\text{, }83\text{, }\redE{83}}_\text{lower half} \text{, }\underbrace{\redE{84}\text{, }84\text{, }84\text{ ,}85}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *even* number of data points. So the median is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $\dfrac{\redE{83} + \redE{84}}{2} = \dfrac{167}{2}= \purpleD{83.5}$  The median is $\purpleD{83.5}$.  We *do not* include the median when we calculate the quartiles, but we *do* include the numbers we averaged to get it.

The **first quartile** is the median of the data points  to the *left* of the median.  $\underbrace{81\text{, }\blueE{82}\text{, }\blueE{83}\text{, }83}_\text{lower half} $  There was an *even* number of data points in the lower half. So the first quartile is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $Q_{1} = \dfrac{\blueE{82} + \blueE{83}}{2} = \dfrac{165}{2}= \maroonD{82.5}$

The **third quartile** is the median of the data points to the *right* of the median.  $\underbrace{84\text{, }\goldE{84}\text{, }\goldE{84}\text{ ,}85}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *even* number of data points in the upper half. So the third quartile is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $Q_{3} = \dfrac{\goldE{84} + \goldE{84}}{2} = \dfrac{168}{2}= \tealE{84}$
$\begin{align} \text{IQR} &= Q_3-Q_1  \\\\ &=  \tealE{84} - \maroonD{82.5} \\\\ &= 1.5 \end{align}$
The interquartile range is $1.5\,\text{cm}$.

question.content: Each dot in the following dot plot represents the essay score of one student in Mr. Harrisburg's class.    **Find the interquartile range (IQR)  of the data in the dot plot.**   points

images.alt: A dot plot has a horizontal axis labeled Score on a 6-point scale numbered from 1 to 6. Dots are plotted above the following: 1, 1; 2, 1; 3, 2; 4, 3; 6, 1.

hints.content: The **interquartile range** is the amount of spread in the middle $50\%$ of the data set.  It is the positive difference between the third quartile and the first quartile.  $\text{IQR} = Q_3-Q_1$

To find the quartiles, let's first find the median by listing the data points from least to greatest.    $\underbrace{1\text{, }2\text{, }3\text{, }\redE{3}}_\text{lower half} \text{, } \underbrace{\redE{4}\text{, }4\text{, }4\text{, }6}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *even* number of data points. So the median is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $\dfrac{\redE{3} + \redE{4}}{2} = \purpleD{3.5}$  We *do not* include the median when we calculate the quartiles, but we *do* include the numbers we averaged to get it.

The **first quartile** is the median of the data points  to the *left* of the median.  $\underbrace{1\text{, }\blueE{2}\text{, }\blueE{3}\text{, }{3}}_\text{lower half}$  There was an *even* number of data points in the lower half. So the first quartile is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $Q_{1} = \dfrac{\blueE{2} + \blueE{3}}{2} = \dfrac{5}{2}= \maroonD{2.5}$

The **third quartile** is the median of the data points to the *right* of the median.  $\underbrace{{4}\text{, }\goldE{4}\text{, }\goldE{4}\text{, }6}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *even* number of data points in the upper half. So the third quartile is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $Q_{3} = \dfrac{\goldE{4} + \goldE{4}}{2} = \dfrac{8}{2}= \tealE{4}$
$\begin{align} \text{IQR} &= Q_3-Q_1  \\\\ &=  \tealE{4} - \maroonD{2.5} \\\\ &= 1.5 \end{align}$
The interquartile range is $1.5$ points.

question.content: Each dot in the following dot plot represents the number of cavities for one patient who visited Dr. White last week.    **Find the interquartile range (IQR)  of the data in the dot plot.**   cavities

images.alt: A dot plot has a horizontal axis labeled Number of cavities numbered from 0 to 8. Dots are plotted above the following: 0, 3; 1, 2; 3, 2; 4, 1; 7, 2.

hints.content: The **interquartile range** is the amount of spread in the middle $50\%$ of the data set.  It is the positive difference between the third quartile and the first quartile.  $\text{IQR} = Q_3-Q_1$

To find the quartiles, let's first find the median by listing the data points from least to greatest.  $\underbrace{0\text{, }0\text{, }0\text{, }1\text{, }\redE{1}}_\text{lower half} \text{, } \underbrace{\redE{3}\text{, }3\text{, }4\text{, }7\text{, }7}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *even* number of data points. So the median is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $\dfrac{\redE{1} + \redE{3}}{2} = \purpleD2$  We *do not* include the median when we calculate the quartiles, but we *do* include the numbers we averaged to get it.

The **first quartile** is the median of the data points  to the *left* of the median.  $\underbrace{0\text{, }0\text{, }\maroonD{0}\text{, }1\text{, }{1}}_\text{lower half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points in the lower half. So the first quartile is the middle number.  $Q_{1} = \maroonD{0}$

The **third quartile** is the median of the data points to the *right* of the median.  $\underbrace{{3}\text{, }3\text{, }\tealE{4}\text{, }7\text{, }7}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points in the upper half. So the third quartile is the middle number.  $Q_{3} = \tealE{4}$
$\begin{align} \text{IQR} &= Q_3-Q_1  \\\\ &=  \tealE{4} - \maroonD{0} \\\\ &= 4 \end{align}$
The interquartile range is $4$ cavities.

question.content: Each dot in the following dot plot represents the number of songs on one of Shane's albums.    **Find the interquartile range (IQR)  of the data in the dot plot.**   songs

images.alt: A dot plot has a horizontal axis labeled Number of songs numbered from 6 to 15. Dots are plotted above the following: 6, 1; 9, 2; 10, 3; 11, 1; 12, 2; 14, 1.

hints.content: The **interquartile range** is the amount of spread in the middle $50\%$ of the data set.  It is the positive difference between the third quartile and the first quartile.  $\text{IQR} = Q_3-Q_1$

To find the quartiles, let's first find the median by listing the data points from least to greatest.  $\underbrace{7\text{, }9\text{, }9\text{, }10\text{, }\redE{{10}}}_\text{lower half} \text{, }\underbrace{\redE{{10}}\text{, }11\text{, }12\text{, }12\text{, }14}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *even* number of data points. So the median is the mean of the two middle numbers.  $\dfrac{\redE{10} + \redE{10}}{2} = \purpleD{10}$  We *do not* include the median when we calculate the quartiles, but we *do* include the numbers we averaged to get it.

The **first quartile** is the median of the data points  to the *left* of the median.  $\underbrace{7\text{, }9\text{, }\maroonD{9}\text{, }10\text{, }{{10}}}_\text{lower half} $  There was an *odd* number of data points in the lower half. So the first quartile is the middle number.  $Q_{1} = \maroonD{9}$

The **third quartile** is the median of the data points to the *right* of the median.  $\underbrace{{{10}}\text{, }11\text{, }\tealE{12}\text{, }12\text{, }14}_\text{upper half}$  There was an *odd* number of data points in the upper half. So the third quartile is the middle number.  $Q_{3} = \tealE{12}$
$\begin{align} \text{IQR} &= Q_3-Q_1  \\\\ &=  \tealE{12} - \maroonD{9} \\\\ &= 3 \end{align}$
The interquartile range is $3$ songs.
